Overall, the pathological stage is pT2a for the bladder carcinoma and pT2b for the prostate adenocarcinoma.

Despite extensive examination, all surgical margins were clear of tumor cells, with a remarkable distance of 1.8 cm from the closest margin. Lymphovascular invasion was confirmed, although no malignancy was detected in the overlying skin. Additionally, multiple microcalcifications were observed. An additional focus of invasive ductal carcinoma, measuring 0.4 cm, was found in tissue superior to the primary tumor, maintaining a clear margin of 1.0 cm. Examination of the left axillary contents revealed metastatic carcinoma in one of thirteen lymph nodes, with extranodal extension and a metastatic tumor size of 2.0 cm. In contrast, the right breast tissue showed no malignancy but did reveal a fibroadenoma. Histological findings characterized the invasive carcinoma as grade 2, featuring glandular differentiation with a score of 3, nuclear pleomorphism with a score of 2, and mitotic count with a score of 2. Importantly, immunohistochemical staining confirmed the presence of estrogen and progesterone receptors, while Her2 scoring was negative (0). These findings culminated in a pathological stage of pT2 pN1a, reflecting primary tumor status and regional lymph node involvement.

Caption:
The patient was diagnosed with bilateral breast carcinomas, consisting of infiltrating lobular carcinoma in the left breast and infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast, both graded as Nottingham grade II (score 7/9). Extensive ductal carcinoma in situ with low to intermediate nuclear grade extends from the primary tumor. This component occupies more than 25% of the mass area and spans beyond the invasive portion. Angiolymphatic invasion is identified. Following re-excision of the anterior/medial margin, all surgical margins are clear of residual tumor with a minimum margin of 0.9 cm. Of the 25 right axillary lymph nodes examined, 4 are positive for metastatic breast carcinoma, leading to an AJCC classification of pN2. The largest metastatic focus includes a collection of matted lymph nodes. Blue dye was noted in the sentinel lymph node assessments for both breasts. Immunohistochemical cytokeratin staining confirmed these findings.

The carcinoma presents as a multi-focal disease, with the primary mass showing angiolymphatic invasion and lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) constituting less than 5% of the overall tumor volume. Additionally, two small nodules of similar-grade invasive lobular carcinoma were identified in the lower outer quadrant, neither of which involves the deep surgical margin. Non-neoplastic breast tissues exhibit both nonproliferative and proliferative fibrocystic changes, along with benign calcifications and biopsy site changes. The mastectomy specimen confirmed the absence of tumor involvement in the nipple, overlying skin, and underlying chest wall, with all surgical margins, including the deep margin, being free of residual tumor. However, a significant finding includes the involvement of five out of eighteen right axillary lymph nodes with metastatic carcinoma, characterized by extranodal extension and the presence of a matted mass. The surgical margins following the mastectomy procedure were conclusively free of residual tumor involvement.

The central tumor mass, measuring 6.4 x 5.2 x 2.5 cm, displays a high nuclear and histologic grade (3 of 3) and presents extensive lymphatic and vascular invasion. The carcinoma is multifocal, with in situ components occupying 5% of the total tumor, specifically of the comedo subtype. Direct invasion into the nipple and overlying skin was observed, with focal involvement of underlying muscle tissue. The surgical margins are compromised, with infiltrating carcinoma present at the lateral margin and in situ carcinoma approaching the deep margins at less than 1 mm distance. Axillary lymph node dissection reveals metastatic ductal carcinoma in 24 out of 30 lymph nodes, with the largest metastasis being 1.2 cm, and extranodal extension is noted. Axillary soft tissue also shows small tumor deposits, which are not clearly linked to lymph node structures. Additionally, non-neoplastic breast tissue exhibits epithelial hyperplasia and apocrine metaplasia. Estrogen receptor activity is positive, whereas progesterone receptor activity is negative.

Caption: The pathological evaluation of the modified radical mastectomy specimen reveals a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma with a high Nottingham score of 3, correlating with a total score of 9/9 due to high nuclear grade (3), tubule formation (3), and mitotic activity (3). Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is present, comprising 25% of the tumor mass and characterized by high nuclear grade, solid and cribriform patterns, and comedo necrosis. The specimen also shows biopsy site changes, atypical ductal epithelial hyperplasia, fibrocystic changes with ductal epithelial hyperplasia, and apocrine metaplasia. Immunohistochemical studies indicate that the tumor is negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors, as well as HER-2/neu (score of 1+). Lymph node involvement is significant, with 10 out of 21 lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma, including extracapsular spread in one node.

Caption: The pathology findings pertain to a female patient with a clinical history of left breast cancer and familial predisposition, who underwent prophylactic bilateral mastectomy. Additionally, a sentinel lymph node from the left axilla was negative for tumor presence upon examination by both light microscopy and immunohistochemistry. An excision from the left lower inner quadrant yielded benign breast tissue with no tumorous cells. This collective histopathological assessment denotes a diagnosis of left breast well-differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma with a benign contralateral breast, clear surgical margins, and no lymph node metastasis.

Microscopic analysis reveals notable mitotic activity and a peritumoral lymphocytic reaction. The examined axillary lymph nodes show reactive lymphadenitis without evidence of metastatic involvement, indicating a pNO status. The immunohistochemical profile of the neoplastic cells is characterized by the absence of estrogen receptors and HER2 protein expression, with progesterone receptors present in fewer than 10% of the cells. Additional histological assessments confirm no pathological changes in the nipple or surrounding tissues. Overall, the tumor exhibits adverse prognostic features based on its high histological grade and hormone receptor status, necessitating a tailored therapeutic approach.

Additional findings include significant vascular proliferation and areas of microvascular permeability, which are indicative of the high-grade nature of this neoplasm.

Caption: The essential pathological findings reveal the diagnoses of three distinct cases: a benign trichilemmoma of the right cheek, a malignant melanoma of the right arm, and an infiltrating adenocarcinoma of the prostate. In contrast, the right arm mass initially suggested a differential diagnosis between malignant melanoma and metastatic carcinoma, but definitive immunohistochemical staining confirmed it as malignant melanoma. BRAF immunostaining was negative, and PCR analysis showed no mutations in the BRAF gene. Finally, microscopic examination of prostate chippings weighing 24 grams revealed infiltrating adenocarcinoma involving more than 90% of the tissue, characterized by a Gleason score of 4+4=8 with a tertiary pattern 5, correlating to a stage of pT1b. These comprehensive findings facilitate appropriate clinical management and therapeutic decision-making for each condition.
